awd_titl_txt: Computer Science for All Researcher Practitioner Partnerships  Technical Assistance Workshop at the University of the District of Columbia
awd_abstract_narration:
As the nation becomes increasingly diverse, it is important that the science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) workforce and body of scholars who will define and implement the K-12 education research agenda include practitioners that reflect that diversity. The University of the District of Columbia (UDC) will convene a Fall 2019 Computer Science for All Researcher Practitioner Partnerships (CSforAll:RPP) Development Workshop in Washington, DC. The National Science Foundation (NSF)'s CSforAll:RPP program focuses on the importance of researcher-practitioner partnerships in supporting computer science (CS) and computational thinking (CT) education. CSforAll empowers our Nation's students to develop skills and competencies in problem-solving, critical thinking, creativity and collaboration that will help them excel in today's increasingly digital and computational world. As a public, historically black and land-grant institution, UDC's responsibility is to build a diverse generation of competitive, civically engaged scholars and leaders. The CSforALL:RPP workshop builds on UDC's culture of teaching and learning as well as on the core values of collaboration and innovation. Through targeted outreach, UDC will engage more minority-serving institutions in the CSforALL:RPP initiative. Workshop teams will receive information, guidance, and access to resources they will need to enhance the capacity of their schools to produce successful CS/CT education outcomes for diverse groups of students.

In partnership with NSF-funded Research+Practice Collaboratory, UDC's project staff will coordinate the event logistics for up to 100 workshop attendees. Participants will include three- to four-person teams of CS education researchers and preK-12 practitioners (teachers, administrators, and counselors), along with other community and industry partners. Logistical planning will include participant team recruitment and registration; arranging meeting room space, catering, and A/V support; and providing reimbursements for travel costs for eligible participants. The 1.5-day workshop will engage teams with different models of RPPs, strategies and tools for forming and maintaining RPPs, and data collection and analysis approaches well-suited to RPPs. Workshop participants will learn how to design and lead RPPs to provide high school teachers with the preparation, professional development and ongoing support that they need to teach rigorous computer science courses; preK-8 teachers with the instructional materials and preparation they need to integrate CS and CT into their teaching; and schools and districts the resources needed to define and evaluate multi-grade pathways in CS and CT. Minority institutions are important incubators of STEM teachers of color--RPPs will assist them in developing/sustaining exemplary teacher education programs, uniquely tailored to equip teachers committed to preparing and inspiring more students from diverse groups to consider computer science careers which in turn, will contribute to America's global competitiveness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Computer Science for All Researcher Practitioner Partnerships (CSforALL:RPP) program "aims to provide all U.S. students the opportunity to participate in computer science (CS) and computational thinking (CT) education in their schools at the preK-12 levels." The University of the District of Columbia (UDC) received NSF support to convene a Fall 2019 CSforAll: RPP Development Workshop to help participating teams develop competitive proposals in response to the FY20 CSforAll RPP solicitation. UDC served as local host for the November 21-22, 2019 Workshop, in Washington, DC, conducted by the National Network of Education Research-Practice Partnerships (NNERPP).

UDC proposed and met the following project objectives:

1)    Convene/host a one-and-a-half-day workshop in Fall 2019 for researcher-practitioner teams;

2)    Recruit, select, and provide logistical support for up to 90 participants;

3)    Provide post-workshop guidance to teams to encourage (re)submission of NSF CSforAll RPP proposals and

4)    Conduct a follow-up survey regarding teams' proposal submission and post-workshop activities.

The UDC project's planning activities included participant recruitment as well as travel and lodging arrangements; securing workshop materials, meeting room space, catering, registration and A/V support; and processing participants' expense reimbursements. Recruitment was conducted via email invitations from UDC to register, using an on-line application hosted at the NNERPP website, via the link to UDC's Workshop webpage. UDC Office of Sponsored Programs (OSP) staff developed a recruitment database using several sources to identify groups of individuals involved in, or with expressed/demonstrated interest in, K-12 focused collaborations or partnerships or leading projects involving teacher preparation and computing literacy. Over 300 invitations were sent by e-mail nationwide, with a special outreach to HBCUs and other minority-serving institutions (MSIs).

Applicants were required to register as 3-4 person teams, with each member fulfilling the following required roles: 1) an educational researcher with K-12 and/or STEM research expertise; 2) an educational partner from an LEA/SEA, school network, or similar K-12 system; 3) a Computer Science or other STEM faculty member with CS/CT expertise; and 4) an optional fourth team member representing community or informal education partners, evaluators, or additional research team members.

UDC and NNERPP selected twenty-two (22) teams (including 7 HBCU-led) for the UDC event, representing 54 organizations. The teams consisted of 84 individuals from 16 states [AL, CO, FL, IL, LA, MD, MI, NC, NY, OH, PA, TN, TX, VA, VT, WV] and the District of Columbia. Also participating were eight (8) RPP coaches, including the NNERRP Director, as well as UDC student hosts and staff from the UDC OSP/Office of Research and NSF. A listserv was developed to facilitate communication and resource sharing.

The UDC-hosted CSforALL:RPP workshop was conducted in November 2019 and event logistics (travel, meals, lodging, evebt space, and materials) successfully executed .Meeting space was secured at the UDC Law School in the auditorium-style Moot Court Classroom and several breakout areas for team working sessions.  Attending were 6 three-person, 14 four-person, and 2 five-person teams from 14 of the 16 states and DC.

This collaborative project provided diverse faculty, including K-12 educators/administrators. and community leaders with training in the development of RPPs and CSforALL:RPP proposal preparation as well as professional development focused on best practices and effective strategies in RPP and K-16 partnership development. The hands-on workshop provided teams with time to work on their research questions, designs, and draft proposals, aided by coaches. NSF Program Directors discussed CSforAll RPP program goals and the criteria for competitive proposals as well as information on related funding opportunities and RPP networks.

Post-workshop, UDC provided information on proposal resources available and deadline reminders to participants via emails. Based on the final design of the workshop, UDC deferred to NNERPP and the coaches who took the lead in providing follow-up guidance to workshop teams via the NNERPP website and webinars. UDC sent February and September 2020 emails to survey participants on their follow-up activities and proposal submission/success as well as to provide relevant updates on travel reimbursements that were delayed due to COVID-related response (campus shift to telework mode).

Thirteen (13) of 15 initial responders to the February email reported their teams were planning on submitting a CSforALL:RPP or related proposal to NSF. Participants continued to engage with their teams and explore collaborations to develop their respective CS and CT teacher training and student learning environments. Nine (9) of 11 teams responding to the September email reported submitting proposals in the FY20 CSforALL competition (2 were not funded; 4 were awaiting results; and 3 were funded). 

A February 2021 review of the NSF awards database by UDC staff showed five (5) teams from institutions represented at the workshop received CSforALL funding. These new RPPs as well as the ongoing collaboration of the workshop teams expand the community of practice that provides all U.S. students the opportunity to engage in CS and CT education in their schools.


Last Modified: 06/26/2021
Modified by: Laura-Lee Davidson
